verses.text: For they said to themselves, thinking wrongly: 'Our life is brief and full of sorrow, and there is no remedy when a person comes to his end, nor has anyone ever returned from death.'
verses.comment: The opening sets up the mindset of the wicked, who see life as fleeting and deny hope beyond death. Contrasts with resurrection hope found in 1 Cor. 15:12–20.

verses.text: We came into being by chance, and after this we will be as though we never existed. For the breath in our nostrils is smoke, and reason is just a spark kindled by the beating of our hearts.
verses.comment: Reflects the materialist outlook and denial of any spiritual soul or afterlife. This directly contrasts the scriptural teaching of the soul's immortality (Luke 20:37–38).

verses.text: When it is extinguished, our body will turn to ashes, and the spirit will dissolve like thin air.
verses.comment: Here the denial of resurrection and the eternal soul is underscored. Cross-references show biblical hope for spiritual existence beyond death.

verses.text: 'Our name will be forgotten in time, and no one will remember our works. Our life will pass away like the trail of a cloud, and will be scattered like mist pursued by sun rays and weighed down by its heat.'
verses.comment: The image of vanishing mist echoes the fragility of temporal life, but Scripture affirms that the righteous are remembered by God (Ps. 112:6).

verses.text: 'Our life is like a shadow that passes; and there is no return from death, for it is sealed so that no one comes back.'
verses.comment: Repeated claim: death is final. Early contradiction of this appears in God’s promises of resurrection (Dan. 12:2).

verses.text: 'Come, then, let us enjoy the good things that exist, and use creation eagerly, as in youth.'
verses.comment: Pursuit of pleasure as ultimate purpose. This hedonistic worldview stands in contrast with biblical calls to holiness (1 Pet. 1:15–16).

verses.text: 'Let us fill ourselves with costly wine and perfumes, and let no flower of spring pass by us.'
verses.comment: Sensual delights prioritized when life is seen as short and without consequence, leading to disregard for virtue.

verses.text: 'Let us crown ourselves with rosebuds before they wither.'
verses.comment: Echoes 'eat and drink, for tomorrow we die' (cf. 1 Cor. 15:32), a mindset that ignores accountability to God.

verses.text: 'Let none of us fail to share in our revelry; everywhere let us leave signs of enjoyment, for this is our portion and our lot.'
verses.comment: The use of material pleasures as ‘alloted’ goods denies deeper spiritual fulfillment.

verses.text: 'Let us oppress the righteous poor; let us not spare the widow or respect the gray hair of the aged.'
verses.comment: Abuse of the defenseless marks the depravity of the wicked. See how God defends widows and the poor in multiple passages.

verses.text: 'Let our strength be the law of right, for what is weak is shown to be useless.'
verses.comment: Strength as source of justice: echoes Nietzschean 'might makes right,' but opposes Scripture's teaching of justice and mercy.

verses.text: 'Let us lie in wait for the righteous man, because he is inconvenient to us and opposes our way of life; he reproaches us for sins against the law and accuses us of sins against our discipline.'
verses.comment: Assault on the righteous foreshadows persecution of Christ (John 7:7).

verses.text: 'He professes to have knowledge of God, and calls himself a child of the Lord.'
verses.comment: Applied to Jesus in the Gospels; the righteous one claiming divine sonship points to the Messiah.

verses.text: 'He has become a reproof to our thoughts.'
verses.comment: The righteous provoke the conscience of the wicked, much as Christ exposes sin.

verses.text: 'His life is different from that of others, and his paths are strange.'
verses.comment: Holiness marks the true servant of God, whose way appears foolish to the world; echoes Christ's counter-cultural example (Matt. 5:44).

verses.text: 'We are considered by him as rubbish, and he avoids our ways as unclean. He calls the final end of the righteous blessed and boasts that God is his father.'
verses.comment: ‘God is his father’: language connected to Jesus’ claims of divine sonship, confirming high Christology.

verses.text: 'Let us see if his words are true, and test what will happen at his end.'
verses.comment: Words echoed at the crucifixion of Christ. The testing of the ‘righteous one’ is a core prophecy of the suffering servant.

verses.text: 'For if the righteous man is God’s son, he will help him and deliver him from the hand of his enemies.'
verses.comment: Directly quoted at Calvary. Prefigures Christ’s passion. Shows the interconnectedness of Old and New Testament prophecy.

verses.text: 'Let us test him with insult and torture, that we may know his gentleness and test his patience.'
verses.comment: The suffering of the righteous foreshadows the passion of Jesus, who responds with perfect patience and gentleness.

verses.text: 'Let us condemn him to a shameful death, for, according to what he says, God will care for him.'
verses.comment: The prediction of a shameful death matches the crucifixion; New Testament writers see this as prophecy regarding Jesus.

verses.text: Such are the thoughts of them, but they are mistaken; for their wickedness has blinded them.
verses.comment: Wickedness darkens the heart and blinds to truth, a recurrent biblical theme. Moral corruption prevents perceiving deeper spiritual realities.

verses.text: They do not know the hidden purposes of God, nor do they understand the reward for holiness, nor discern the prize for blameless souls.
verses.comment: Points to the mystery of God’s plan and the reality of reward for the just—a key theme of Christ’s teaching (Matt. 5:12).

verses.text: For God created man for incorruption, and made him in the image of his own nature.
verses.comment: Teaches that humanity is ordained for immortality. This foundational concept connects to belief in bodily resurrection and the sanctity of the imago Dei.

verses.text: But through the envy of the devil, death entered the world, and those who belong to him experience it.
verses.comment: Original sin introduced death. This lays the groundwork for the doctrine of humanity’s need for redemption through Christ. Prefigures the centrality of the cross and resurrection.
